ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
In-person seminar
asynchronous sessions
Workshopping projects via Google Docs
had individual meetings with our capstone advisors (not exactly part of the course but worked in conjunction with it)

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about how to ask a research question, plan and stick to a timeline, and gather research.
I learned how to do research in the field of education and write a grant proposal.

Good lord, what DIDNT I learn? I learned how to articulate my ideas with passion, specificity, clarity, and articulation. I learned how to organize my own thinking, reflect on my own learning, and ask for help. I learned to not give up on myself and stand behind my words. I have never worked harder for a class, and I'm so glad that I did. What a great opportunity!
I learned how to manage a long research project, implement feedback on a regular basis, and how to better conduct research. Clas helps you better understand your research style
I developed my capstone and my approaches to masculinity studies.
I got a lot of help for my capstone.
Research organization skills, what a lit review is
I learned how to design a research project.

- How to properly develop a research question and methodology.
- Research organization strategies
- Building a comprehensive  project prospectus

i learned a lot about various research tools, especially for sorting through lots of sources and keeping notes on them in a clear and useful way. i also learned a lot about my personal learning style and work methods by having flexibility in the course to tailor assignments to what would be most helpful to me. there were some good short exercises that helped me get clear and concise with articulating my project to others.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: peer edit sessions were very helpful, Professor TZB and TF Anne were always willing to help and push students to do better. I received a ton of feedback from multiple people weekly.

Strengths: the support of the professors and TAs in the class, along with the peers and workshops. The class is hard but there is so much support that you will learn a lot through the process and also feel confident while doing so. 
Weaknesses: none

Strengths: Opportunities 
Weaknesses: 

Room for improvement: At times the flexibility of the class could get a little annoying if I wanted to *work,* but I ultimately think that it's necessary, especially given how people will be in different places with their projects at any given time. I would rather the flexibility than too much stringence.
Strengths: The course is very well organized and helps keep you on track in terms of making initial progress. The feedback was also really helpful as I was beginning my project.

Strengths: support from teacher and ta, flexibility, feedback 
Weaknesses: only get to interact with a small group of other students out of whole class. Wouldve like to work with different students
The deadlines were extremely constricting, it felt impossible at times.

Strengths: TZB & Anne are the most amazing humans I ever met. 

Cons: Covid

Because the course was small and with a cohort of familiar faces, there was a lot of time given to individual student projects. The intermittent assignments leading to the final prospectus were also helpful in flushing out research and staying on track throughout the semester. 

The biggest downside was how early the class began every Tuesday.

strengths: structured but flexible; lots of feedback from peers, tzb, and anne; required you to reflect on your own work honestly, judged on progress more than content itself, felt casual and comfortable, kept you on track with your work

weaknesses: early in the morning and week, it's hard because everyone's creative project looks so different but i think there could be better support for creative projects sooner in the semester (i.e. moving all people with creative projects to working on the creative part right after the modules, giving a list of alumni who've done creative projects that we could reach out to, etc), lots of assignments

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Breakout rooms and a lot of discussions definitely helped. We also would get a 5-minute stretch break in the middle of the class, which was super helpful.
N/A
There were asynchronous sessions and a lot of lax deadlines which helped with the difficult situation.

- Zoom/Breakout Rooms were effective for workshopping sessions

- Google Docs allowed students to collaborate on projects asynchronously

succeeded: could have cameras off, could eat or drink in class, used the chat well for different writing exercises, incorporated us all using some other sites at the same time like google sheets

could be improved: would've been nice to have a little break (~5-10 min) in the middle of class because it's a long class and screen time that early in the morning can be hard on the eyes

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to those who are looking to do research of any kind in their future.
Yes, 100%. The course and the instructors are fantastic.

100%. It's going to be quite difficult, because it's about confronting and growing as a writer, researcher, and human being. It's valuable as hell and I'm so glad that I did. EDST seniors should really take this course, because you'll have a wonderful opportunity to really push yourself on a topic that you're passionate about and design original research (which doesn't have to be empirical!). I promise that you'll grow immensely as a person and student. This class is as difficult as you want it to be, and I promise, you'll crave that challenge. At the same time, you'll have the most understanding, flexible, supportive mentors EVER in the process.
I would recommend this to Ed Study scholars since you have to take it. It is a good thesis course though
Yes.
Maybe.
Absolutely!

i would definitely recommend it. helped keep me on track for my capstone and checked me when i wasn't making the progress i should have. most majors don't have this level of support for theses, so it was really nice to have and it felt like the techniques and skills i learned from it were applicable to other projects i was working on.

extras.title:
EDST 400 01
        Advanced Topics in Ed Studies
